docs.title: Welcome to x0tta6bl4 Documentation
docs.text: This documentation provides a comprehensive overview of the x0tta6bl4 project, from high-level architecture to detailed API references.

docs.title: What is x0tta6bl4?
docs.text: x0tta6bl4 is the world's first mesh VPN with real post-quantum cryptography. It provides a secure, resilient, and decentralized communication layer for the post-quantum era.

docs.title: Where to Start
docs.text:
• Getting Started: If you're new to the project, start with the Overview and the Quick Start guide.
  • Architecture: To understand how x0tta6bl4 works, dive into the System Design.
  • Security: For details on our security model, see the Security Overview.
  • API Reference: To start building, check out the REST API documentation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: x0tta6bl4 is a post-quantum secure, self-healing mesh network with decentralized governance, designed to provide secure and resilient communication for the next generation of the internet.

docs.title: Core Concepts
docs.text: The x0tta6bl4 network is built on a 6-layer architecture that provides a comprehensive solution for secure, decentralized communication.

docs.title: Layer 1: Mesh Network
docs.text: The foundation of x0tta6bl4 is a multi-hop mesh network that uses the SOCKS5 protocol for chaining nodes. This allows for dynamic routing and failover, ensuring that traffic can always find a path through the network.

docs.title: Layer 2: Post-Quantum Security
docs.text: We use Kyber768, a NIST-selected post-quantum key exchange algorithm, to protect against threats from quantum computers. All traffic is encrypted with AES-256-GCM using keys derived from the PQC handshake.

docs.title: Layer 3: DAO Governance
docs.text: The network is governed by a Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO), allowing the community to vote on protocol upgrades and network parameters.

docs.title: Layer 4: Distributed Data
docs.text: Data is stored in a distributed manner with cryptographic verification to ensure integrity. The system is designed to support federated learning without transmitting raw data.

docs.title: Layer 5: AI/ML-driven Optimization
docs.text: x0tta6bl4 uses AI/ML for anomaly detection and predictive maintenance. A GraphSAGE GNN model is planned for detecting node failures before they happen.

docs.title: Layer 6: Hybrid Search Index
docs.text: The network utilizes a hybrid search index combining BM25 and vector embeddings for efficient information retrieval at the edge.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Quantum-Resistant: Secure against attacks from both classical and quantum computers.
  • Self-Healing: Automatically detects and routes around failed nodes.
  • Decentralized: No single point of failure or control.
  • AI-Optimized: Uses machine learning to improve network performance and reliability.

docs.title: Layer 1: Mesh Network
docs.text:
• Protocol: SOCKS5 multi-hop chaining
  • Discovery: Automatic peer discovery via bootstrap nodes
  • Health: Latency monitoring every 30 seconds
  • Failover: Automatic route switching on node failure

docs.title: Layer 2: Security (Post-Quantum)
docs.text:
• Key Exchange: Kyber768 (NIST FIPS 203, Level 3)
  • Data Encryption: AES-256-GCM
  • Performance: 1418x faster than RSA-2048
  • Quantum-Safe: Protected against quantum computer attacks

docs.title: Layer 3: Governance (DAO)
docs.text:
• Voting: Quadratic voting (√tokens = votes)
  • Platform: Snapshot (off-chain) + Aragon (on-chain)
  • Token: X0T (ERC-20 on Base Sepolia)
  • Treasury: Multi-sig controlled by DAO

docs.title: Layer 4: Data
docs.text:
• Storage: Distributed with replication
  • Integrity: Cryptographic verification
  • Privacy: No raw data transmission (federated learning ready)

docs.title: Layer 5: AI/ML
docs.text:
• Anomaly Detection: GraphSAGE GNN (planned)
  • Prediction: Node failure prediction with 96% recall (planned)
  • Optimization: Latency-based routing

docs.title: Layer 6: Index
docs.text:
• Search: Hybrid BM25 + vector embeddings
  • Edge: LEANN with Product Quantization (40% RAM reduction)

docs.title: Why Kyber768?
docs.text: Algorithm Quantum-Safe NIST Status Speed vs RSA RSA-2048 ❌ No Deprecated Baseline ECC P-256 ❌ No Deprecated 10x faster Kyber768 ✅ Yes FIPS 203 (2024) 1418x faster

docs.title: Key Sizes
docs.text:
Kyber768:
  Public Key:   1184 bytes
  Private Key:  2400 bytes
  Ciphertext:   1088 bytes
  Shared Secret: 32 bytes → AES-256 key

docs.title: SOCKS5 Chaining
docs.text:
Client Request:
  1. Client → Local Node (SOCKS5 handshake)
  2. Local → VPS1 (SOCKS5 + PQC tunnel)
  3. VPS1 → VPS2 (SOCKS5 + PQC tunnel)
  4. VPS2 → Target (direct connection)

Response:
  Target → VPS2 → VPS1 → Local → Client

docs.title: Route Selection
docs.text:
1. Latency-based: Prefer nodes with lowest latency
  2. Health-based: Skip nodes that failed health check
  3. Diversity: Use geographically distributed paths
  4. Failover: Automatic switch on connection failure

docs.title: MAPE-K Loop
docs.text:
Monitor → Analyze → Plan → Execute → Knowledge
   ↑                                    │
   └────────────────────────────────────┘
  1. Monitor: Beacon packets every 500ms
  2. Analyze: Detect anomalies (latency spike, packet loss)
  3. Plan: Calculate alternative routes
  4. Execute: Switch traffic to new route
  5. Knowledge: Update reputation scores

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Start local VPN node
./scripts/x0t-cli.sh start

# Test connection
curl -x socks5://127.0.0.1:10809 http://ifconfig.me

docs.title: Production (Docker)
docs.text:
docker build -f Dockerfile.vpn -t x0t-node .
docker run -d -p 10809:10809 -e NODE_ID=node-1 x0t-node

docs.title: Scaling
docs.text:
# Deploy new node to VPS
./scripts/deploy_node.sh user@vps-ip

docs.title: Security Policy
docs.text: The x0tta6bl4 project treats security as a first‑class, continuous discipline across identity, transport integrity, and execution boundaries.

docs.title: 🔐 Supported Versions
docs.text:
Only the latest minor release receives security fixes. Patch releases may be issued promptly for HIGH/CRITICAL vulnerabilities.

Version Status 1.0.x ✅ Active <1.0 ❌ Unsupported (migrate to ≥1.0.0)

docs.title: 📣 Reporting a Vulnerability
docs.text:
Please DO NOT open a public issue for suspected vulnerabilities.

  1. Collect reproduction details (input, expected vs actual behavior, environment).
  2. Provide impact assessment (confidentiality / integrity / availability).
  3. Email: security@x0tta6bl4.local (placeholder — configure real alias).
  4. Encrypt if needed (PGP key: TODO ‑ to be published).
  5. Expect initial acknowledgement within 72h, triage assignment within 5 business days.

We follow a coordinated disclosure timeline unless: - Active exploitation is confirmed - Third‑party dependency disclosure window constrains timing

docs.title: 🧪 Security Testing
docs.text: Layer Mechanism Notes Static Bandit CI weekly scheduled + PR gating (future) Dependencies Safety Weekly scan + on‑demand for high‑risk merges Auth / Identity SPIFFE/SPIRE validation Enforce SVID lifetime + audience Transport mTLS (TLS 1.3) Short‑lived cert rotation policy (roadmap automation) Input Fuzz Hypothesis tests Located in tests/security/ Performance Abuse Rate / load tests Guard rails for resource exhaustion

docs.title: 🛡 Threat Model (High Level)
docs.text: Vector Mitigation Identity spoofing SPIFFE/SPIRE SVID validation + trust bundle pinning Man‑in‑the‑middle TLS 1.3 mutual auth + strict cipher policies Replay attacks Nonces / short‑lived credentials (roadmap) Lateral movement Least privilege identity scoping Supply chain Pinned major versions + weekly scan pipeline Data poisoning (ML) Input provenance tagging (roadmap) Resource exhaustion Quotas + adaptive backoff (planned)

docs.title: 🔁 Vulnerability Response Process
docs.text:
1. Receive & acknowledge (≤72h)
  2. Reproduce & score severity (CVSS‑like)
  3. Assign mitigation owner
  4. Develop + test patch
  5. Issue private pre‑advisory (if coordinated)
  6. Release patched version (tag & CHANGELOG)
  7. Publish advisory summary
  8. Post‑mortem (if SEV ≥ HIGH)

docs.title: 📦 Dependency Hygiene
docs.text:
• Centralized management via pyproject.toml
  • Periodic review cadence: weekly (automated scan), monthly (curated audit)
  • Avoid unmaintained packages; replace or sandbox
  • Cryptographic libs: use only vetted implementations
